Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Shout \Shout\ (shout), v. i. [imp. & p. p. {Shouted}; p. pr. & vb. n. {Shouting}.] [OE. shouten, of unknown origin; perhaps akin to shoot; cf. Icel. sk[=u]ta, sk[=u]ti, a taunt.] 1. To utter a sudden and loud outcry, as in joy, triumph, or exultation, or to attract attention, to animate soldiers, etc. [1913 Webster]
Shouting of the men and women eke. --Chaucer. [1913 Webster]
They shouted thrice: what was the last cry for? --Shak. [1913 Webster]
2. To entertain with refreshments or the like gratuitously; to treat. [Slang, Australia & U. S.] [Webster 1913 Suppl.]
{To shout at}, to utter shouts at; to deride or revile with shouts. [1913 Webster]
shouted adj : in a vehement outcry; "his shouted words of encouragement could be heard over the crowd noises" [syn: {yelled}]
